title: Paul Scharner
text:
Paul Josef Herbert Scharner (born 11 March 1980) is an Austrian retired <a href="Association%20football">footballer</a>. He operated mainly as a <a href="Defender%20%28association%20football%29%23Centre%20back">defender</a>, although he could play almost every <a href="Midfielder%20%28association%20football%29">midfield</a> position as well. He was known for his great positional versatility and haircuts.
Scharner started his professional career with <a href="Austrian%20Football%20Bundesliga">Austrian Bundesliga</a> sides <a href="FK%20Austria%20Wien">Austria Wien</a> and <a href="FC%20Red%20Bull%20Salzburg">SV Salzburg</a>, before moving to <a href="Norway">Norwegian</a> <a href="Tippeligaen">Tippeligaen</a> in late 2004, starting for <a href="SK%20Brann">SK Brann</a>. In January 2006, he entered the <a href="Premier%20League">Premier League</a> where he played for over six years, playing for <a href="Wigan%20Athletic%20F.C.">Wigan Athletic</a> and <a href="West%20Bromwich%20Albion%20F.C.">West Bromwich Albion</a>, respectively. After a short time as a <a href="free%20agent">free agent</a>, he transferred to <a href="Bundesliga">Bundesliga</a> veteran club <a href="Hamburger%20SV">Hamburger SV</a> in August 2012, before returning to <a href="Wigan%20Athletic%20F.C.">Wigan Athletic</a> on loan in January 2013 - winning the <a href="FA%20Cup">FA Cup</a>. He announced his retirement, at age 33, in September 2013.
Early life and youth career.
Born in <a href="Scheibbs">Scheibbs</a>, Scharner grew up in <a href="Purgstall%20an%20der%20Erlauf">Purgstall an der Erlauf</a>, where he also started his playing career with local site SVG Purgstall at the age of seven, playing for the club's U-8 team. He stayed with the club until 1993, when he transferred to FCN St. Pölten, which he left in 1996 for <a href="FK%20Austria%20Wien">Austria Wien</a>, the club where he would receive his first professional contract in 1999. He played for their U-17 and U-18 and later for the club's amateurs, while also getting <a href="vocational%20education">vocational education</a> in the field of <a href="electrical%20engineering">electrical engineering</a>.
Professional career.
Austria Wien.
After rising through the youth ranks of the club and playing for the U-17, U-18 and amateur squads, he made his debut for the first team as a substitute on the third of March in 1998 in a <a href="exhibition%20game">friendly match</a> against Hellas Kagran, which <a href="FK%20Austria%20Wien">Austria Wien</a> won 5:1<ref name="Austria Wien Archiv: Paul Scharner 97/98 season"></ref> and received his first professional contract in May 1999.
1998/1999 and 1999/2000 seasons
Before receiving his first professional contract with the club, he again took part in two friendly matches in February 1999, before making his debut in the <a href="Austrian%20Football%20Bundesliga">Austrian Bundesliga</a> on 24 April in a <a href="home%20%28sports%29">home game</a> against <a href="SV%20Ried">SV Ried</a>, which the Austria won 3:0. In May, he took part in three games for the remainder of the season, playing against <a href="SV%20Austria%20Salzburg">Salzburg</a>, <a href="Grazer%20AK">GAK</a> and <a href="FC%20Tirol%20Innsbruck">Innsbruck</a>, respectively. The latter also marked his first time in the starting line-up and his first <a href="Penalty%20card%23Commonly%20used%20penalty%20cards">yellow card</a>.<ref name="Austria Wien Archiv: Paul Scharner 98/99 season"></ref>
Similar to the last season, Scharner played the first team only in friendly matches at the beginning, before returning to the Bundesliga in the eleventh round on 11 September against GAK as a substitute, in mid October against <a href="SW%20Bregenz">SW Bregenz</a> as a time stoppage and in late November against <a href="LASK%20Linz">LASK Linz</a>. In total he made twelve appearances in the league, nine of which as a starter, while receiving three yellow cards. He made his <a href="%C3%96FB-Cup">ÖFB-Cup</a> debut in the second round in late October against SV Würmla and returned for four other matches, while being crucial for the loss against <a href="SV%20Salzburg">SV Salzburg</a> by receiving a second yellow card in the 23rd minute of play. He scored his first two goals for the Austria in a friendly match against Wiener Neudorf in February.<ref name="Austria Wien Archiv: Paul Scharner 99/00 season"></ref>
2000/2001 and 2001/2002 seasons
His first matches in the new season also marked his debut on the international stage, playing four matches in the <a href="UEFA%20Intertoto%20Cup">UEFA Intertoto Cup</a>, competing with <a href="Nea%20Salamis%20Famagusta%20FC">Nea Salamis Famagusta FC</a> and <a href="FC%20Ceahl%C4%83ul%20Piatra%20Neam%C5%A3">Ceahlăul Piatra Neamţ</a>, respectively. That season, he made only one appearance in the ÖFB-Cup, in the second round against Wiener Neustadt. In the league, he firstly played in the ninth round against Bregenz, but did not become a part of the team again until the 16th round, but played every game until the 23rd round then. After that, his appearances became fewer until the end of the season. He collected a total of three yellow cards that season, playing 14 games.<ref name="Austria Wien Archiv: Paul Scharner 00/01 season"></ref>
To further develop his skills and to give him more minutes, Scharner was loaned to then-Austria affiliate club SG Untersiebenbrunn in the <a href="Austrian%20Football%20First%20League">Erste Liga</a> from July to October 2001, where he scored five goals in 16 league matches and also played in the ÖFB-Cup. He returned to his club in November and started getting minutes by the end of the month, playing against <a href="Rapid%20Wien">Rapid Wien</a>, SV Salzburg and <a href="FC%20K%C3%A4rnten">FC Kärnten</a>. In the second half of the season he developed himself as a starter, seeing the kick-off in twelve of his 13 games, while seeing four yellow cards that season. He made his first goal for Austria Wien in a professional competition, opening the scoring in a Bundesliga match against <a href="Sturm%20Graz">Sturm Graz</a> on 30 March.<ref name="Austria Wien Archiv: Paul Scharner 01/02 season"></ref> His strong away round also brought him into the <a href="Austrian%20national%20football%20team">Austrian national football team</a>, debuting in a 0:0 against <a href="Cameroon%20national%20football%20team">Cameroon</a> on 17 April 2002.
2002/2003 and 2003/2004 seasons
After having emerged as a regular starter in the second half of the previous season, he played 29 league games this season, starting 22 of them and seeing eight yellow cards. He scored his only league goal that season in a home game against GAK. He played every cup game starting from the 1/8 finale, seeing one yellow card. Austria also competed in the <a href="UEFA%20Cup">UEFA Cup</a>, playing against <a href="Shakhtar%20Donetsk">Shakhtar Donetsk</a>, sweeping them 5:1 in the first game and against <a href="F.C.%20Porto">Porto</a> in the second round, both games were lost.<ref name="Austria Wien Archiv: Paul Scharner 02/03 season"></ref> His breakthrough season also marked his most successful with the club, as Austria won the Bundesliga, the ÖFB-Cup and the <a href="Austrian%20Supercup">Austrian Supercup</a>.
Scharner played nine league games for Austria Wien the next season, scoring one goal and receiving three yellow cards until September, as well as competing in the <a href="UEFA%20Champions%20League">UEFA Champions League qualification</a> against <a href="Olympique%20Marseille">Olympique Marseille</a>, losing the home game and tying in the away game, which led to an UEFA Cup match against <a href="Borussia%20Dortmund">Borussia Dortmund</a>, which was also lost.<ref name="Austria Wien Archiv: Paul Scharner 03/04 season"></ref> He was kicked from the team in mid October, after then-coach <a href="Joachim%20L%C3%B6w">Joachim Löw</a> intended to substitute him as a right midfielder, a position he did not like to play. After refusing his substitution and later stating: "The coach and I discussed where I can help the team the most, but the coach always uses me elsewhere. I already played on seven different positions. But I'm continuing my path." he was suspended from Austria and was forced to look for a new team.
SV Salzburg.
Having no future with <a href="FK%20Austria%20Wien">Austria Wien</a>, Scharner was forced to look for a new team and ended up playing for <a href="FC%20Red%20Bull%20Salzburg">SV Austria Salzburg</a>, who were at that time fighting against relegation, signing a contract until June 2006.
After being kicked by <a href="Joachim%20L%C3%B6w">Joachim Löw</a>, Scharner transferred to relegation battler SV Salzburg in January to help them for the rest of the season. He made a total of 13 league games for Salzburg that season, 4 of which were won and three tied, scoring two goals, against <a href="FC%20Admira%20Wacker%20M%C3%B6dling">Wacker Mödling</a> and <a href="SC%20Bregenz">Bregenz</a>, respectively. He saw his first yellow/red card in a 3:2 win against <a href="FC%20K%C3%A4rnten">Kärnten</a>, the same site that kicked Salzburg out of the 1/8 finale in the ÖFB-Cup, sweeping them 4:0. He collected a total of five yellow cards that season. The team managed to avoid relegation at the end of the season.<ref name="tipp3-Bundesliga Archiv 2003/2004 season"></ref>
Although the relegation was avoided last season, Scharner surprisingly pressed a transfer to <a href="SK%20Brann">SK Brann</a> shortly before the closure of the transfer window, leaving Salzburg early in the season. In his short stint with Salzburg that season, Scharner made a total of five league matches, scoring one goal against Bregenz and receiving one yellow and one yellow/red card.
SK Brann.
After avoiding relegation with <a href="FC%20Red%20Bull%20Salzburg">Salzburg</a>, Scharner was expected to fulfill his contract, but surprisingly pressed a transfer to Norwegian <a href="Tippeligaen">Tippeligaen</a> club <a href="SK%20Brann">SK Brann</a> on the last day of the summer transfer period. He signed a 2.5-year contract.
Having transferred to Brann late in the season, Scharner made only a few games for his new club, scoring one goal. Brann won the <a href="Norwegian%20Cup">Norwegian Cup</a> that season, thus qualifying for the <a href="UEFA%20Cup">UEFA Cup qualification</a>, where they overcame <a href="AC%20Allianssi">AC Allianssi</a>, but lost both games against <a href="Lokomotiv%20Moscow">Lokomotiv Moscow</a> the next round.
The following year, he developed himself into a starter for the Norwegian side, playing 29 games while scoring five goals and receiving four yellow cards. When he left the club after the 2005 season, he had played 32 league matches, scoring seven goals. Scharner was elected Brann's Player of the Year in 2005.
Wigan Athletic.
After finishing the 2005 season with <a href="SK%20Brann">SK Brann</a>, Scharner signed a 3.5-year deal with <a href="Wigan%20Athletic%20F.C.">Wigan Athletic</a> on 22 December 2005, and joined the squad after the holidays. Wigan agreed to pay a fee of £2,500,000 (€3,700,000, 29,500,000 NOK), making it the biggest transfer in Brann's history.
Scharner joined Wigan for the second half of the <a href="2005%E2%80%9306%20Wigan%20Athletic%20F.C.%20season">2005–06 season</a>. In his first match for Wigan, Scharner scored the winning goal against <a href="Arsenal%20F.C.">Arsenal</a> in the <a href="2005%E2%80%9306%20Football%20League%20Cup">League Cup</a> at the <a href="JJB%20Stadium">JJB Stadium</a>. He went on to start in the final for Wigan that season, a 4–0 defeat to <a href="Manchester%20United">Manchester United</a>. He scored his first <a href="Premier%20League">Premier League</a> goal in the 24th round in a 1–1 draw with <a href="Everton%20F.C.">Everton</a>. He quickly emerged as a starter, playing all games from the 22nd round onwards, scoring three goals while receiving five yellow cards.
He continued his leading role the <a href="2006%E2%80%9307%20Wigan%20Athletic%20F.C.%20season">next season</a>, again battling relegation with Wigan. He started for much of the first half of the season, scoring two goals in an away-tie against Everton, receiving five yellow cards in that half of the season. Injury kept him off the field for much of the second half, returning not until the 30th round in a match against <a href="Fulham%20F.C.">Fulham</a>. he collected four yellow cards this time around and scored one goal in the last game of the season, a 1–2 away-win against <a href="Sheffield%20United%20F.C.">Sheffield United</a>. This one goal proved to be crucial that season, as his performance in the game safed Wigan from relegation at the final day of play, sending their opponent to <a href="Football%20League%20Championship">The Championship</a> instead, by a goal difference of just one.
The <a href="2007%E2%80%9308%20Wigan%20Athletic%20F.C.%20season">2007–08 season</a> saw Wigan battling relegation once again. Again, Paul Scharner was a vital part of the team, starting in almost every game of the season, while scoring four goals and receiving six yellow cards. He scored his first goal of the season in the fourth round against <a href="West%20Ham%20United">West Ham United</a>. He helped his team with a goal in the third round of the <a href="FA%20Cup">FA Cup</a> against <a href="Sunderland%20A.F.C.">Sunderland</a> but Wigan lost to <a href="Chelsea%20F.C.">Chelsea</a> in the next round. Wigan finished the season on the 13th place, having earned 40 points,<ref name="League Table 2007/2008 season"></ref> while Scharner was elected Wigan's player of the year.
Aside from reaching the third round in the FA Cup and the fourth in the League Cup, Scharner made a total of 27 league games the <a href="2008%E2%80%9309%20Wigan%20Athletic%20F.C.%20season">following season</a>, scoring no goals while receiving three yellow cards, lifting Wigan Athletic to a solid eleventh place, having earned 45 points.<ref name="League Table 2008/2009 season"></ref> On 22 March 2009, he became the first Wigan player to play 100 Premier League games, playing an outstanding 77 minutes in a 1–0 win at home to <a href="Hull%20City%20A.F.C.">Hull City</a>.
In his <a href="2009%E2%80%9310%20Wigan%20Athletic%20F.C.%20season">final season</a> for Wigan, he played in all 38 league games, scoring four goals while receiving six yellow cards. Wigan lost to <a href="Blackpool%20F.C.">Blackpool</a> in the second round of the League Cup and to <a href="Notts%20County">Notts County</a> in the fourth round of the FA Cup. On 30 August 2009, he scored his first goal of the season against Everton. After a 5–0 defeat to Manchester United, Wigan manager <a href="Roberto%20Mart%C3%ADnez">Roberto Martínez</a> preferred to use Scharner in an attacking midfield role. Scharner was a part of the team in November 2009 that suffered a historical 9–1 loss at the hands of <a href="Tottenham%20Hotspur%20F.C.">Tottenham</a>, scoring Wigan's only goal in the fixture although, when controlling the ball prior to shooting, he appeared to <a href="handball%20%28soccer%29">handle</a> it. On 19 April 2010, he announced his decision to leave Wigan Athletic at the end of the 2009–10 season.<ref name="Bosman/Free Transfer List: England – Premier Leaguen"></ref>
West Bromwich Albion.
On 30 August 2010, Scharner joined newly promoted <a href="Premier%20League">Premier League</a> site <a href="West%20Bromwich%20Albion%20F.C.">West Bromwich Albion</a> on a two-year deal, having been a <a href="free%20agent">free agent</a> since his release by <a href="Wigan%20Athletic%20F.C.">Wigan</a>. Teammate <a href="James%20Morrison%20%28footballer%29">James Morrison</a> has since praised his performances, saying that although Scharner is "a weirdo", has made a positive impact on the team. He made the switch to West Brom with the intent of no longer playing in central defence when manager <a href="Roberto%20Di%20Matteo">Roberto Di Matteo</a> told him he will be used as a midfielder.
After his league debut in a 1–1 draw against <a href="Tottenham%20Hotspur%20F.C.">Tottenham Hotspur</a> in the fourth round, West Brom went on a five-game unbeaten run, including a win against <a href="Arsenal%20F.C.">Arsenal</a> and a draw against <a href="Manchester%20United">Manchester United</a>. He scored his first goal for Albion against <a href="Everton%20F.C.">Everton</a>. West Brom also reached the third round of the <a href="FA%20Cup">FA Cup</a> that season. He received seven yellow cards and was sent off once that season, while scoring four goals. His club finished <a href="2010%E2%80%9311%20Premier%20League">the season</a> in eleventh place with 47 points.<ref name="League Table 2010/2011 season"></ref>
The <a href="2011%E2%80%9312%20West%20Bromwich%20Albion%20F.C.%20season">next season</a>, his final year in the Premier League, he played 29 games for West Brom, mostly as a starter, scoring three goals, while receiving six yellow cards. His team reached the third round in the <a href="League%20Cup">League Cup</a>, losing to Everton. West Brom earned 47 points again, finishing on tenth place.<ref name="League Table 2011/2012 season"></ref> After not meeting a clause in his contract that would trigger a twelve-month extension, Scharner announced on 8 May that he would be leaving West Brom in the summer and search for a new challenge.
Hamburger SV.
After his contract with <a href="West%20Bromwich%20Albion">West Bromwich Albion</a> ended, Scharner was linked to <a href="Eintracht%20Frankfurt">Eintracht Frankfurt</a> but after absolving a week of training there, Scharner was not signed by Frankfurt and instead moved to <a href="Bundesliga">Bundesliga</a> veteran club <a href="Hamburger%20SV">Hamburger SV</a>, where he received a two-year contract. When talking to coach <a href="Thorsten%20Fink">Thorsten Fink</a> for the first time prior to signing his contract, he prepared a list of ten questions he wanted to ask his new coach, a fact that surprised and impressed Fink.
Return to Wigan.
After four senior <a href="2012%E2%80%9313%20Bundesliga">Bundesliga</a> appearances in the 2012–13 season with <a href="Hamburger%20SV">Hamburg</a>, Scharner was signed on loan by former club <a href="Wigan%20Athletic%20F.C.">Wigan Athletic</a>, on <a href="transfer%20window">transfer deadline day</a>. He helped the club to reach the <a href="2012%E2%80%9313%20FA%20Cup">FA Cup</a> final after they beat <a href="Millwall%20F.C.">Millwall</a> 2–0 at <a href="Wembley%20Stadium">Wembley</a>. Scharner said it was his "best moment in football". On 11 May 2013 Scharner won the <a href="2013%20FA%20Cup%20Final">FA Cup</a> with Wigan, playing the whole game in a 1–0 upset win against <a href="Manchester%20City%20F.C.">Manchester City</a>. Only three days later, Wigan were relegated from the Premier League following a 4–1 defeat against Arsenal.
International career.
Scharner started playing for Austria at the <a href="Austria%20national%20under-21%20football%20team">under-21 level</a>, debuting against <a href="Spain%20national%20under-21%20football%20team">Spain</a> in 2000. He played a total of twelve matches on that level, scoring no goals.
Scharner debuted for the <a href="Austrian%20national%20football%20team">Austrian national football team</a> in a 0–0 draw with <a href="Cameroon%20national%20football%20team">Cameroon</a> on 17 April 2002. He played the <a href="2006%20FIFA%20World%20Cup%20qualification">qualification round</a> for the <a href="2006%20FIFA%20World%20Cup">2006 FIFA World Cup</a> but Austria failed to qualify. Scharner retired in August 2006 after a 2–1 defeat to <a href="Hungary%20national%20football%20team">Hungary</a>, criticising "unprofessional structures" within the <a href="%C3%96FB">ÖFB</a>. Coach <a href="Josef%20Hickersberger">Josef Hickersberger</a> banned him from the team and stated that he will never play for Austria as long as he manages it. He tried to make a comeback in 2008, when Austria co-hosted the <a href="2008%20UEFA%20European%20Championship">2008 UEFA European Championship</a> but Hickersberger remained hard, not picking him. After Hickersberger was replaced, his successor <a href="Karel%20Br%C3%BCckner">Karel Brückner</a> started nominating him again after the tournament and he was even promoted to team captain from 2009 to 2010. After then-coach <a href="Dietmar%20Constantini">Dietmar Constantini</a> was fired, he tried to become player-coach but this was rejected. In August 2012 he was banned from the team permanently after leaving the team hotel when coach <a href="Marcel%20Koller">Marcel Koller</a> refused to give him a leading role in the upcoming <a href="2014%20FIFA%20World%20Cup%20qualification">2014 FIFA World Cup qualification</a>. The chairmanship of the ÖFB has stated that he will never play for Austria again, no matter who coaches it. He played a total of 40 matches, scoring no goals.
Style of play.
Scharner usually serves as a central defender or midfielder. Nevertheless, he is noted for his positional flexibility, having played every outfield position for Wigan except left back. This versatility was already evident early in his career. While at <a href="FK%20Austria%20Wien">Austria Wien</a> his former coach <a href="Joachim%20L%C3%B6w">Joachim Löw</a> played him in various positions and although, over his career he has performed well whatever position he has been selected to play, he has let it be known he prefers playing in a defensive position. His former coach at <a href="West%20Bromwich%20Albion">West Brom</a>, <a href="Roberto%20Di%20Matteo">Roberto Di Matteo</a>, describes Scharner as follows: "Paul is a powerful, competitive player who is good on the ball, excellent in both boxes, can play in numerous positions and also chips in with goals."
Another feature of his play is his great professionalism and focus, planning his training, goals and achievements meticulously on flip-charts. Since he was twelve, he has controlled his nutrition and since he was fifteen he has trained with Valentin Hobel; a personal mental coach. He practices his mental and autogenous training with great discipline, as he regards it as fundamental for his success as a professional. Scharner believes, "You can train your mind as well as your body." His <a href="Hamburger%20SV">HSV</a> coach <a href="Thorsten%20Fink">Thorsten Fink</a> said, regarding his leadership abilities: "Paul is the type who never hides, who always leads the way and who will be there for the team especially in close situations."
Image.
Scharner's disputes with coaches at both club and international level have brought him media attention: a 2012 feature in "<a href="%C3%96sterreich%20%28newspaper%29">Österreich</a>" described him as "still an awkward customer" (). In 2003, his refusal to come on as a substitute to play on the right of midfield led <a href="FK%20Austria%20Wien">Austria Wien</a> coach <a href="Joachim%20L%C3%B6w">Joachim Löw</a> to suspend him from the team. After Scharner announced his retirement from international football in 2006, citing the ÖFB's lack of professionalism, national coach <a href="Josef%20Hickersberger">Josef Hickersberger</a> said that as long as he was in charge, Scharner would not play for Austria again. He made a comeback under <a href="Dietmar%20Constantini">Dietmar Constantini</a>, but criticised the retention of Constantini as coach after failure to qualify for <a href="Euro%202012">Euro 2012</a>, proposing himself as a better alternative. His final breach with the national team came in August 2012, when the ÖFB banned him permanently for leaving the team hotel after unsuccessfully demanding a guaranteed key role throughout the <a href="2014%20FIFA%20World%20Cup%20qualification">World Cup qualifiers</a> and publicly criticising coach <a href="Marcel%20Koller">Marcel Koller</a>.
In Norway he was affectionately given the nickname "fussballgott" (i.e. "football-god"), and called "a cross-over between <a href="Franz%20Beckenbauer">Franz Beckenbauer</a> and <a href="Norman%20Hunter%20%28footballer%29">Norman Hunter</a>". Although claimed to be an "enfant terrible", he was lauded for having an ability of self-examination, and for being "a leading figure, an idol and a resourceful member of the team". In England, he is remembered largely for his professionalism, focus and his energetic performances, as well as his close relationship and identification with the fans of his former teams.
He is also known for his various haircuts, cutting and dying his hair in a multitude of fashions and colours.
Personal life.
Paul Scharner is married to Marlene and has three sons: Constantin, Benedict and Paul Jr. He has received <a href="vocational%20education">vocational education</a> in the field of <a href="electrical%20engineering">electrical engineering</a> and lists <a href="skiing">skiing</a>, <a href="Reading%20%28process%29">reading</a>, <a href="motorcycling">motorcycling</a> and <a href="Pool%20%28cue%20sports%29">billiards</a> as his personal interests.
